body:
### Problem

```lua
--- @class vim.api.keyset.hl_info.cterm : vim.api.keyset.hl_info.base
--- @field ctermfg? integer
--- @field ctermbg? integer
--- @field foreground? integer
--- @field background? integer

--- @class vim.api.keyset.hl_info : vim.api.keyset.hl_info.base
--- @field fg? integer
--- @field bg? integer
--- @field sp? integer
--- @field default? true
--- @field link? string
--- @field blend? integer
--- @field cterm? vim.api.keyset.hl_info.cterm
```

but when calling `vim.api.nvim_get_hl` I see fields like `ctermbg` and `ctermfg` directly in the object returned by it.

### Steps to reproduce

Run `nvim -u NONE`

Execute command `:hi Normal ctermbg=1` and then:

```
:lua print(vim.api.nvim_get_hl(0, {name = "Normal"}).ctermbg)
```

prints `1`.

```
:lua print(vim.api.nvim_get_hl(0, {name = "Normal"}).cterm)
```

prints `nil`.

### Expected behavior

I'd expect the values to be set according to the type definition, or that the type definition is correct so I don't get any warnings when addressing a property that is deemed not to exist.

### Neovim version (nvim -v)

v0.10.0

### Vim (not Nvim) behaves the same?

vim does not have Lua API

### Operating system/version

Arch Linux

### Terminal name/version

Alacritty 0.13.2 (bb8ea18e)

### $TERM environment variable

screen-256color

### Installation

Arch linux repo
title: Bug in `vim.api.keyset.hl_info` type definition
